abstract: <jats:p>For the first time, we obtained for the first time a COI DNA barcode from museum specimens of the Old World swallowtail butterfly endemic to Taiwan, <jats:italic>Papilio machaon</jats:italic> ssp. <jats:italic>sylvina</jats:italic>, that has disappeared since the devastating Jiji earthquake in 1999 that shook Central Taiwan. We demonstrate that this population was not only phenotypically distinct, but also had a unique mitochondrial haplotype among all other Holarctic populations of <jats:italic>P</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>machaon</jats:italic>. The life history of <jats:italic>P</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>m</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>sylvina</jats:italic> from rearing experiments carried out in the 1990s is illustrated and discussed.</jats:p>
title: Wiped out by an earthquake? The ‘extinct’ Taiwanese swallowtail butterfly (Lepidoptera, Papilionidae) was morphologically and genetically distinct
